item.title: Comment on Friday assorted links by Ed77
item.description:
Reply to Jonathan W Siegel:

#1: Made me feel very sad for the writer. Here he is in his mid-fifties (according to another commenter) and he's still thinking about status and one's position on it. By then, adults typically being to realize that building your life around ascending to the highest possible status, whatever that is, is a fool's errand.

I find that "essay" non only misjudged, but also dangerous. It's the kind of message that promotes conformism on steroids - sure, let's all apply to Ivy League and then get a job at McKinsey, what can go wrong?

I tell you what can go wrong. I was at Accenture too, and I was a top performer there, to the point I convinced myself I deserved better. Got an MBA, pivoted to finance, and managed to get an offer as trader at a top investment bank. At my new employer, I soon found myself at the bottom quartile, and got fired in one of those redundancies rounds that Wall Street goes through every couple years.

I reckon it took me 5-7 years to put my career back on some decent footing. Once I factor in the cost of an MBA, the lost compensation, the emotional impact of getting fire - I still wonder whether it was worth it.

Unfortunately most people lack the potential for being a tech founder or a successful trader. I appreciate that's not the target readership of MR, which I'm sure includes many accomplished people. But the candid advice I wish I got in my early 20s is that performance is always relative. So yes, choose your status hierarchy wisely.

item.title: Comment on Noah Smith on the vibe shift by Leo
item.description:
Reply to Swing State Voter:

Yeah I don't get when people like Noah are pointing to her campaign points as proof that they are going to get what they want or a more "conservative" administration. Talk is cheap, and as a swing state voter I have to look at records. There is almost always a disconnect between campaigning and governing and as a voter you have to sniff that out.

The fact is that Kamala when in power (senate + tie breaking vote in senate + border czar) has done nothing but endorse and enable leftist policy. How am I supposed to square that now? The "I was just VP" works fine for the last four years (VP's really don't have any power), but she has never explained how her senate stint and 2020 run don't represent her views. One doesn't go from the farthest left senator to being a centrist overnight. How is that going to reflect on her cabinet/admin appointments? Should I expect to see it full of warren-ites like Gary Gensler still?

With Trump however, he's been in office before and has been fairly consistent on the things I care about the most. Kamala may or may not be tough on the border but I know for a fact Trump will.

FWIW I voted Biden in 2020 because I was under the impression he would be more moderate than he turned out being.

People like Noah who point to her campaign as proof that she is "moderating" are basically rubes who want to be duped.
